text: after the biggest route in markets for
two years on Thursday markets today
climbed slowly higher to end flat but
that was after a very wild ride they
opened higher in the morning after
better than expected jobs numbers showed
that the American economy wasn't as bad
as people had feared but then they began
to fall has investors once again focused
on Europe's problems centered now on
Spain and Italy only in the afternoon
when rumors started to swirl the markets
that the European Central Bank would
finally step in and try to help Spain in
Italy did the markets climb higher in
Italy today Prime Minister Silvio
Berlusconi came out and promised
structural reform in his economy and
spending cuts and greater austerity and
that's seen as him keeping his half of
the bargain which may pave the way for
the European Central Bank in Frankfurt
to come in and support Italy and its
bond markets there are short-term
measures to help the financial markets
in Spain and Italy but if these
countries needed full-blown bailouts
there's the real fear that the funds put
in place by Europe would be overwhelmed
by the scale of problems in these two
highly indebted countries and in the
u.s. there is still weak growth next
week people will be looking to the Fed
which meets on Tuesday to see if it's
going to do more to help mend the
economy and perhaps inject more money in
some sort of way
you
